title: What are some must hear Ukrainian songs of any genre? - Quora

response.answer_text: Let me add some of my faves! kozaksystem are absolutely a favourite of mine. 10/10 They mostly do rock but have quite a few lyrical songs. ПИРЯТИН harsh, but damn good. Not for everyone, but I’ll link my fav song from them below OT VINTA have the absolute best humour. You wanna make your Ukrainian friends laugh their bottoms off you put on these guys ONUKA - if you’re into techno, she’s your gal! Riffmaster Band - classic rock NAVKA - her voice is so good! She does pop, and has a collection of classical Ukrainian folk songs. And a list of other bands before it gets too long: MOTANKA - heavy rock https://www.youtube.com/user/VivienneMortTV/videos - pop https://www.youtube.com/user/odynvkanoeofficial/videos - acoustic guitar and voice verrrry nice FliT / ФЛІТ - punk Epolets - another punk band to follow ;) They rock! Ціна Ритму - rap! We do have good indie rap bands :D https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCWJULrY4qhbj0pqnNOrYETg/videos - hiphop or rap? I’m not good at telling those styles apart. Fun funky songs tho https://www.youtube.com/c/alyonaalyona another great rap singer! Check her out for lightning fast Ukrainian rap Now for my fav featured songs! When She… - my absolute favourite song.  Autumn Has Your Eyes… - the softest most lyrical song they have  Pass the Weapon, Brother - THE song about war against Russia  Artillery - a cheerful song from Piryatin  Ukrainian Army Anthem - this one gives me shivers in the best ways  I Shouldn’t Have Eaten the Onions - tfw you ate a bunch of onions and met a pretty girl  Make Love - an old poem by Taras Shevchenko given new life  Quote from Autobiography - another song that gives me shivers.  Svitanok (Sunrise) - one of my favs from ONUKA  Silently Came, Silently Left - an ode to special forces  We Girls Be Like That - this song bops  Kozaks Woke Up at Dawn - same singer as above! Her voice makes me shiver in this one  Alyona Alyona - Open Up https://youtu.be/2FCMJ31i8Yg This did end up being long, didn’t it? That’s because we have lots of great music!

Probably the Ukrainian song most instantly recognizable to people in the West is “Carol of the Bells” (Щедрик) by Ukrainian composer Mykola Dmytrovych Leontovych, which was based upon a traditional Ukrainian folk chant, and is usually heard at Christmas.  A popular Ukrainian song that is practically the unofficial national anthem is “Chervona Ruta,” written by Volodymyr Ivasyuk. You will hear it anywhere Ukrainians gather to sing and is covered by virtually every Ukrainian band and singer.  The national instrument is the uniquely Ukrainian bandura. The B&B project are a group of Ukrainian musicians who popularize traditional instruments by playing everything from covers of popular rock and pop songs to classical favorites to traditional and modern Ukrainian songs.  "Й уберемо куста" is a jazzy/folk/pop song by Ilaria. It is a type of song you might hear at a Eurovision competition.  Another mainstream pop sound is “Friend” by a band from Sumy called The Elephants.  Rock fans will appreciate The Hardkiss.  If you are looking for something a little funkier, I recommend “Rozy Donbass” by Dakh Daughters, a seven women band who are equal parts musicians and theatrical performers.  Also, a band that interprets traditional Ukrainian folk songs with a modern twist is DakhaBrakha, my favorite Ukrainian band. Their song, “Carpathian Rap,” is a fun song about a village girl with too many boys to choose from.  DakhaBrakha played “Yanky” at Glastonbury, where it was a hit with the crowd, as you can see.  “Yahudky” is a haunting song, also by DakhaBrakha, and my personal favorite.

I scrolled down to glance at what others suggest and it broke my heart. With all respect, most of these songs are old, sad and dusty ones. As a representative of a younger generation of Ukraine I`d like to speak on behalf of fresh and modern music of my country. We are (mostly) not living in huts and playing banduras anymore. We can make the music of XXI sentury too :) So here are a few of my favorites. I chose only the ones in Ukrainian. Panivalkova. Three girls who play a few dozens of insrtuments. And their music sounds like magic. Unfortunately, they`ve already split up.  Latexfauna. I`ve been to their concert three years ago when there were barely a dozen of people. Now they`re having sold-outs everywhere they go. They sound like no one else. Unfortunately, you might not be able to feel how terrific this band is due to the language. They use not pure Ukrainian language but this untranslatable dialect called “surzhyk’. And in their case it sounds fun and natural and totally worthy.  Jadan and the Dogs. Something that you might not totally get too. Jadan (I`m quite sure that it`s spelled like Zhadan, but in this video they wrote it with J, so let it be) is the poet who writes mostly about the Woman and the dirty realism of dark ages of Ukraine (the 90th) or living in the deep province (which is still somewhere around 90th). And his music (ska-punk) is quite the same. Bandit-ish I would say :) This one, for example, is about booze.  Postman. Simple, but fair. This one is about Kyiv streets. Makes me cry and love my city even more.  He also plays in one of my favorite bands 5 Vymir. Light and charming.  Boombox, eternal classics :) Almost as old and dusty, as Okean Elzy, which someone here has already recommended. But when you`re sad and need to become even more sad - that`s exactly what you need. (The Gitas are nice too, actually).  Here`s the same one in Spanish, hurts me so much that I can`t breathe.  Alina Pash. She tried to start her career in Ukrainian tv-show like “The Voice” but, as for me, she was just another girl with fancy voice and no spark, boooring. But look at her now! She mixes western Ukrainian traditional motives with quite modern approaches. And looks and sounds so stylish, I`m in love.  Alyona Alyona. She came out of nowhere, created this video and woke up famous. Almost like Justin Bieber did, but she is better (says me who can`t stand rap music at all!). The video may look pretty weird, but it has it`s own charisma :)  They also sang together ;)  Yuko. Another interpreters of Ukrainian traditional music.  They also have a duo with already mentioned by others amazing Dakh Daughters.  And bonus track. Atomic Simao. Something psychedelic from the outter space. In case you like such things.  And bonus track number 2. Brunettes shoot blondes sing in English, but they are marvelous (you definrtely should see the video!). To be honest, for the long time I thought they were British…  I hope you`ll enjoy it! I also have a long list of English-singing artists. Can help you with that too :)

It doesn't translate consistently in English: but a generally accepted version is Plyve Kacha. It is a folk song, some 600 years old now: but it speaks to the risks and costs of war. It also has become a kind of rallying cry for the Maidan protests in Kiev in 2014. It's a beautiful song if you understand Ukrainian, and has traditionally been sung as a conversation: but I heard a version sung as a lament. It was amazing. It was done I think in 2016, on The Voice Ukraine, Holos Krainy. The complete song can be found on YouTube. It's worth seeing. It was sung by Inna Ishchenko, and she played the bandura while she sang. It is haunting, beautiful, and sends a powerful message. Thank you Michael! When I wrote this I couldn't remember her name. It's been many years since I knew Ukrainian, and not enough to live in country-but I still understand the song and still love it. I may also be incorrect in the traditional meaning I give this song: a couple of great friends of mine from Belarus taught me the song and the language (they were both fluent), and they told me what the song means in a national context. If I erred, my apologies. It's still a great song though.

Okean Elzy (Океан Ельзи in Ukrainian, which means Elsa’s Ocean) is, according to Wikipedia:[1] one of the most successful and popular Ukrainian rock bandsnot only in Ukraine but also in most CIS countriesI cannot judge, since I’ve never been to Ukraine, nor any other country of the Commonwealth of Independent States. But I — through circumstances I don’t want to get into — have a few songs of their excellent laid-back rock on my playlist that I absolutely adore, even if I don’t understand a word. Part of which is due that you can’t understand a word even as a Ukrainian, or so I’ve been told. What’s more, since Ukrainian sounds a little like Russian (to me, at least), Russian native speakers will say, “What in the world is this guy singing about?” before realizing it’s not their language after all. Anyhow, without further ado, here are my four favorite songs by Okean Elzy: Isn't it сон (Isn’t it a dream?) Ікони не плачуть (Icons Don’t Cry) Вiдчуваю (Feeling) Сьюзi (Susie) Footnotes[1] Okean Elzy - Wikipedia

While I am Polish and not Ukrainian, I happen to love Ukrainian folk songs do to their melody, depth, wide sound range and melancholic nature. One of my favorite Ukrainian folk songs is Oj Czyj to Kiń Stoit (I cant write in cyrillic) It is a song about a Kozak who is in love with a girl, but the girl is giving her love to another man.  And here below is a more modern rendition  Being a Pole, I also love Hej Sokoly, which is shared by both Poles and Ukrainians. It is about a Kozak who is leaving his beloved Ukraine, and is also bidding farewell to his girl. Here is the Ukrainian version.  And here is the Polish version.  The next song is a very beautiful song, titled The Sun Sets. It is a ballad about betrayal in love.

Ukraine is well-known for its lyric folk songs. This playlist is selected for the best song and performer: :: Songs of Ukraine : Пісні України :: Highlights:Teren.   Mother.  Bat'ko ("Father") Makhno.  Modern hits playlist: :: Ukraine Today :: Highlights: The Dream.  Without Fight.  Hail.  --------------------------------------------------------------And, of course, popular rock version of Ukrainian anthem:

1. Shche ne vmerla Ukraina (the national anthem)2. Ty zh mene pidmanula (a folk song) - see video below.3. Plyve kacha po tysyni (a folk song) - see video below. Other than that, see Music of Ukraine.Depending on your age and musical tastes, I could list a few more, some very unconventional, such as music by Verka Serduchka (watch the Eurovision 2007 performance, for example). See video below.

A song about the quiet happiness of two lovers. And silence can show that you can’t say with words.  The song is about that good and love always win.  A song about love and trust.  The song about the spring  Sad song about love.  The song is about unrequited love and that youth passes but leaves memories.  Prophetic song about the Russian-Ukrainian war. Written before the war. About the person who died in the struggle, but lived with dignity.  And many, many other songs.

Playlist:  The soul of the ukrainian nation is in folklore songs and music. Ukrainians, particularly in the Eastern Ukraine have fostered a peculiar style of singing - white voice. This type of singing primarily exploits the chest register and is akin to controlled screaming. The vocal range is restrictive and in a lower tessitura. In recent times vocal courses have been established to study this particular form of singing.

Fresh one: “Плакала” by Kazka.  Older one: “лиш вона” by “плач Єремії”.  You might like the band “Океан Ельзи”, they have a lot of good songs. For example I like “911” :)  There are much more, of course.

As a Ukrainian I would suggest:Folk songs:1) Ніч яка місячна  2) Чорнії брови, карії очі  3) Ой чорна я си чорна  4) Їхав козак за дунай  As modern songs:1) Океан Ельзи - Не твоя війна  2) KAZKA — ПЛАКАЛА  3) Khrystyna Soloviy - Trymai  4) Скрябін - Місця Щасливих Людей.  And there are many more.Those are just some of my preferred…

Carol of the bells Shchedryk is likely the best known carol from Ukraine     Here in a beautiful video by VV (Vopli Vidopliassova) Vopli Vidopliassova - Shchedryk     I also suggest Nu Virgos (originally called Via Gra)
Here are some songs I personally like Antytila “Tam de my ye”Arsen Mirzoyan “Buvay malyi”Okean Elzy “A ya na nebi”Kuzma “Stari fotografii”Bumboks “Naodyntsi”

I don’t know many Ukrainian songs, but since I saw that my favorite one isn’t mentioned, so here it is: Я піду в далекі гори  Here you have the lyrics and translation. Another beautiful rendition by a child with an amazing voice:
This one. There's no contest, really.
This one. I believe you’ll love it. The first video is a kind of modern version, the second one is original.
Most Ukrainian songs are folk music. I don’t think this song is Ukrainian, but if you search “Freestylo” on youTube it’s entertaining.
